description: Anonymized, UI-optimized patient timeline data for web interface
data_notes: All patient names anonymized. Locations generalized to state/country only. Events simplified for UI consumption.

events.description: Cavity completely disappeared on CT scan

events.notes: Doctors monitoring growth for now. Patient concerned but no immediate intervention planned.

disease.severity: moderate (cavitary disease with 1.8cm upper right lobe cavity, normal lung function, considering surgery after 1 year medical therapy)

events.description: MAC diagnosed with 1.8cm cavity in upper right lobe
events.notes: Patient in 40s, normal lung function at diagnosis. Cavity located in upper right lobe.

events.description: Started antibiotic treatment (oral antibiotics, details unspecified)
events.notes: Started oral antibiotic treatment shortly after diagnosis

events.description: Added Arikayce for 3 months trial
events.notes: Arikayce added because cavity was not shrinking as expected with oral antibiotics alone

events.description: Experienced brain fog from Arikayce
events.notes: Side effect significant enough to contribute to discontinuation decision

events.description: Cavity showed no shrinkage during Arikayce trial
events.notes: Despite 3 months of Arikayce, cavity size remained unchanged at 1.8cm

events.description: Switched from Arikayce back to inhaled Amikacin
events.notes: Returned to previously effective medication after Arikayce failure

events.description: Historical data: inhaled Amikacin previously achieved 20% cavity shrinkage
events.notes: Patient has history of positive response to inhaled Amikacin (cavity reduced from ~2.2cm to 1.8cm, representing 20% shrinkage). This influenced decision to return to inhaled Amikacin after Arikayce failure.

events.description: Surgical consultation - weighing options after 1 year of antibiotics with insufficient cavity shrinkage
events.notes: NYU ID doctor says most patients cured after surgery. NJH recommended IV Amikacin (patient not sensitive to it). Patient considering posterior segment resection. Concerned about IV Amikacin side effects (hearing loss, fungal infections, gut/liver/kidney effects). Strong candidate for surgery but hesitant.

events.description: Decision to continue medical management through end of 2025 before surgical decision
events.notes: Patient decided to complete 18 months of antibiotics (through end of 2025) and reassess cavity size before making final decision on surgery.

timelines.key_insight: Patient at critical decision point after 12 months of treatment with suboptimal cavity response. 1.8cm cavity persists despite oral antibiotics + inha

disease.species: Mycobacterium abscessus (subspecies abscessus with erm41 resistance gene)
disease.severity: moderate (pneumonia, successfully treated with 9 months intensive therapy)

events.description: Diagnosed with pneumonia caused by Mycobacterium abscessus
events.notes: Initial diagnosis of M. abscessus pneumonia

events.description: Started intensive 9-month treatment: 5 months IV + oral, then 4 months oral + nebulized
events.notes: Intensive M. abscessus treatment with IV phase followed by oral/nebulized phase

events.description: Transitioned from IV to oral + nebulized antibiotics after 5 months
events.notes: Stepped down from IV to less intensive oral + nebulized regimen

events.description: Completed 9-month M. abscessus treatment course
events.notes: Successfully completed intensive M. abscessus treatment protocol

events.description: Long-term follow-up: 13+ years without M. abscessus recurrence (2009-2022+)
events.notes: Exceptional long-term success for M. abscessus. Patient maintains strict environmental precautions.

events.description: Ongoing environmental precautions to prevent reinfection
events.notes: Patient takes proactive environmental precautions: Pall filters on all water sources, avoids tap water, makes travel decisions based on NTM risk. Chose Cabo over Hawaii due to lower NTM incidence.

timelines.key_insight: Exceptional long-term M. abscessus success story: 13+ years (2009-2022+) without recurrence after 9-month intensive treatment. Patient completed 5 mon

disease.species: Mycobacterium abscessus erm41 (initial infection, highly drug-resistant variant), later recurrence with different M. abscessus variant (2025)
disease.severity: moderate to severe (bronchiectasis, recurrent infections despite treatment)

events.description: M. abscessus erm41 (highly drug-resistant) diagnosed via bronchoscopy
events.notes: Initial diagnosis of highly drug-resistant M. abscessus erm41 variant via bronchoscopy. Treatment delayed by 4 years.

events.description: Started intensive M. abscessus treatment: 3 oral drugs + 2 IV drugs (PICC line)
events.notes: Complex M. abscessus treatment with 5 simultaneous antibiotics (3 oral + 2 IV). PICC line placed for IV administration at home. Weekly then bi-weekly bloodwork required. Weekly clinic visits for PICC line maintenance. Patient and family trained to administer IV drugs at home.

events.description: Stopped doxycycline due to adverse side effects
events.notes: First medication discontinuation due to intolerable side effects

events.description: Stopped amikacin IV due to hearing loss

side_effects.action_taken: Medication discontinued, now requires hearing aids

events.notes: CRITICAL ADVERSE EVENT: Permanent hearing loss from amikacin IV. Patient emphasizes this was preventable with better monitoring. Now requires hearing aids permanently. This represents a major quality-of-life impact that patient attributes to insufficient medical oversight.

events.description: Continued remaining protocol (2 oral drugs only) for 9 more months after stopping amikacin
events.notes: Patient completed treatment with reduced regimen (oral antibiotics only) after stopping both doxycycline and amikacin. Notable cosmetic side effects: dark tan skin, eye color change, orange bodily fluids. Treatment required significant lifestyle restrictions: couldn't leave town for entire treatment period due to IV infusions, weekly clinic visits, bloodwork requirements.

events.description: Completed M. abscessus treatment course (~13 months total, reduced from original plan)
events.notes: SURPRISING OUTCOME: Despite stopping 2 of 5 medications early (doxycycline at 4mo, amikacin timing unclear), M. abscessus was completely cleared. Patient notes this was unexpected - goal was suppression, not eradication. Demonstrates that even incomplete/modified M. abscessus regimens can occasionally achieve cure.

events.description: M. abscessus recurrence ~8 years post-treatment, different variant than original erm41
events.notes: Recurrence after ~8 years with DIFFERENT M. abscessus variant (not original erm41). Patient is asymptomatic/minimally symptomatic: active physically and socially, minimal cough, minimal sputum. No lesions. This represents likely reinfection rather than relapse since it's a different variant.

events.description: Watchful waiting - managing without treatment, delaying retreatment
events.notes: Patient REFUSING treatment despite positive cultures. Rationale: severe previous side effects (especially permanent hearing loss), currently asymptomatic. Managing with airway clearance, saline nebulization, staying active. This represents informed patient decision to prioritize quality of life over aggressive treatment when asymptomatic. Medical team has not identified environmental source despite two separate M. abscessus infections ('the doc says because I've had abscessus twice there must be a susceptability but we've not been able to determine the specific source').

timelines.key_insight: COMPLEX RECURRENCE CASE with critical clinical lessons. Initial treatment (2017-2018): M. abscessus erm41 treated with 5 antibiotics (3 oral + 2 IV).

disease.species: Multiple species (sequential/concurrent): Pseudomonas, MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex), Mycobacterium abscessus, Aspergillus
disease.severity: severe (progressive multi-species infections, recurrent cavitary disease, declining PFTs despite aggressive treatment, considering lung transplant)
comorbidities: Type I collagen genetic defect (familial, daughter also affected)

events.description: Diagnosed with Pseudomonas + MAC + M. abscessus + cavitary disease
events.culture_result: positive for Pseudomonas, MAC, and M. abscessus
events.notes: Triple-species infection at diagnosis with cavitary disease

events.description: Started PICC line with 2 IV medications + oral omadacycline

side_effects.action_taken: Prescribed Zofran (ondansetron) to be taken 1+ hour before Nuzyra

events.notes: Initial aggressive treatment with PICC line for multi-species infection. Omadacycline caused severe nausea requiring anti-nausea medication.

events.description: Right lower lobe (RLL) wedge resection to remove cavity thought to be causing M. abscessus
events.notes: Surgical intervention targeting M. abscessus source cavity

events.description: PICC line removed after achieving stability, started clofazimine + Arikayce (continued omadacycline)

side_effects.side_effect: Tan skin that became scaly (giraffe-like appearance)

events.notes: Post-surgery stabilization achieved. M. abscessus cleared from cultures. Transitioned from IV to oral/nebulized regimen.

events.description: Aspergillus discovered in LEFT lung (new cavity), galactomannan levels elevated
events.culture_result: positive for Aspergillus, also MAC detected
events.notes: NEW COMPLICATION: Despite treating original infections, aspergillus emerged in OPPOSITE lung with new cavity. Bronchoscopy couldn't determine cavity etiology but galactomannan levels warranted aspergillus treatment. MAC also detected but prioritized aspergillus treatment.

events.description: Added voriconazole for aspergillus treatment
events.notes: Treatment escalation to address aspergillus. Now on 4+ medications: voriconazole, clofazimine, Arikayce, omadacycline

events.description: Added Big 3 components (clarithromycin + ethambutol) for MAC treatment
events.notes: MASSIVE TREATMENT ESCALATION: Now on 6+ simultaneous medications for multiple species (aspergillus, MAC, preventing M. abscessus recurrence): 1) Voriconazole (aspergillus), 2) Omadacycline, 3) Arikayce, 4) Clofazimine, 5) Clarithromycin (MAC), 6) Ethambutol (MAC). Managing nausea with Zofran.

events.description: One year post-surgery: M. abscessus negative but MAC + aspergillus persist, continuing to develop new cavities, worsening PFTs
events.culture_result: M. abscessus negative, MAC positive, Aspergillus positive
events.notes: MIXED OUTCOME: Surgery successfully cleared M. abscessus (negative cultures for 1 year), but disease progressed with MAC and aspergillus persisting. NEW CAVITIES continue to form despite aggressive 6-drug regimen. PFTs declining.

events.description: Referred for lung transplant evaluation
events.notes: CRITICAL ESCALATION: Disease progression despite aggressive treatment has led to transplant evaluation. Patient pessimistic about eligibility due to: 1) M. abscessus history (contraindication), 2) Age, 3) Osteoporosis (with T6 compression fracture), 4) Type I collagen genetic defect (familial mutation, increases infection susceptibility). Patient hopeful for brensocatib (new bronchiectasis drug pending FDA approval Aug 2025).

events.description: Compression fracture T6 vertebra discovered on CT (for bronchoscopy navigation)
events.notes: ADDITIONAL COMPLICATION: Compression fracture T6 discovered (osteoporosis-related). This further complicates transplant eligibility and overall health status.

timelines.key_insight: EXCEPTIONAL CASE demonstrating multi-species progression despite aggressive treatment. TIMELINE: Initial diagnosis with Pseudomonas + MAC + M. abscess

classification.educational_value: high (drug-resistant MAC management, surgical decision-making after failed medical therapy, serious medication side effects including clofazimine eye crystals, newer drug regimens including bedaquiline/tedizolid, treatment discontinuation due to intolerable side effects, phage therapy as last resort)

timelines.key_insight: HIGHLY EDUCATIONAL CASE demonstrating: 1) DRUG-RESISTANT MAI management challenges (macrolide-resistant strain requiring alternative regimens), 2) NEW

comorbidities: suspected rheumatoid arthritis (later ruled out - markers low, attributed to infection)

classification.educational_value: very_high (RARE extrapulmonary MAC case - <5% of MAC infections, post-surgical infection acquisition, persistent infection despite multiple debridement surgeries, wound management challenges including wound vac, rifampin intolerance requiring PICC line amikacin, secondary infections complicating treatment, care coordination challenges across multiple specialties, systemic healthcare navigation issues, caregiver burden, early retirement due to treatment demands)

timelines.key_insight: HIGHLY EDUCATIONAL RARE CASE demonstrating: 1) EXTRAPULMONARY MAC INFECTION (<5% of MAC cases, usually in immunocompromised or post-surgical patients)

Started Big 3 antibiotics for MAC

Added IV amikacin via PICC line to regimen for treatment intensification

Progressive clinical deterioration on Arikayce: severe shortness of breath, tachycardia requiring multiple cardiac medications, 24/7 oxygen dependence, housebound for months

side_effects.action_taken: multiple cardiac medications prescribed, cardiologist evaluation

Stopped Arikayce and airway clearances to prevent further pneumothoraxes from violent coughing
Started Dupixent (dupilumab) as alternative treatment approach for MAC/bronchiectasis
Started pulmonary rehabilitation program, continuing Dupixent, slow gradual improvement ongoing
events.culture_result: 4 negative cultures achieved, then 1 positive culture (May 2025)

timelines.key_insight: CRITICAL ARIKAYCE FAILURE and ALTERNATIVE TREATMENT case demonstrating IMPORTANT patterns: 1) ARIKAYCE PARADOXICAL WORSENING: Progressive clinical det

disease.species: MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex) in 2018, followed by M. avium intracellulare subspecies chimaera in 2019 - sequential infections
disease.disease_type: Sequential NTM infections: MAC (2018) followed by chimaera (2019)
disease.severity: severe

events.description: First NTM diagnosis: MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex). Patient experienced severe debilitating fatigue and nonstop coughing that caused bedridden status.
events.notes: Severe initial presentation with quality of life severely impacted. Patient bedridden during this period.

events.description: Environmental source investigation conducted with Dr. Ted Naureckas from University of Chicago. Identified room air humidifier as probable NTM exposure source.
events.notes: Critical educational point: Environmental source identification crucial for success. Patient now avoids all mist humidifiers. This detective work likely prevented future reinfections.

events.description: Started Big 3 antibiotics (azithromycin, ethambutol, rifampin) for MAC treatment under care of Dr. Ted Naureckas at University of Chicago.
events.notes: Standard MAC treatment protocol. Duration: 12 months total for both infections.

events.description: Second NTM diagnosis: M. avium intracellulare subspecies chimaera - back-to-back infection while still symptomatic from MAC. Patient remained bedridden with continued debilitating fatigue.
events.notes: Challenging case: Sequential infections with MAC followed by chimaera. Patient remained severely debilitated through both infections.

events.description: Genetic testing performed at Mayo Clinic Rochester at recommendation of Dr. Ed Chan (National Jewish Health/VA). Testing revealed single gene mutation (x1282) for cystic fibrosis, explaining patient's susceptibility to NTM and other maladies.
events.notes: Critical educational finding: CF gene mutation (x1282) explains NTM susceptibility. This information helps patient and family understand risk factors and need for ongoing vigilance.

events.description: Completed 12 months of Big 3 antibiotics covering both MAC and chimaera infections. Treatment successfully cleared both infections.
events.notes: Treatment success: Both MAC and chimaera infections cleared with standard Big 3 regimen. Total treatment duration: 12 months.

events.description: Long-term sustained negative status. Patient has had no recurrence of NTM since completing treatment in 2019. As of September 2024, remains 5+ years negative with full recovery and return to active lifestyle.
events.notes: Exceptional long-term success: 5+ years sustained negative (as of Sept 2024). Full return to active lifestyle including daily swimming (half mile) and full-time work. This represents true 'success story' addressing thread's central question.

events.description: Patient achieved full recovery and return to high-quality active lifestyle. Working full-time and swimming half mile daily - activities that would have been impossible during bedridden period.
events.notes: Powerful quality of life recovery: From bedridden with debilitating fatigue to swimming half mile daily. Patient's story specifically shared to provide hope to others, addressing thread's request for 'successful stories' and 'role models/poster child to encourage everyone here!'

timelines.key_insight: Exceptional long-term success story: 5+ years sustained negative (as of Sept 2024) after sequential MAC and chimaera infections. Patient achieved comp

disease.severity: not specified

events.description: Diagnosed with MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex), Pseudomonas aeruginosa (light growth), and bronchiectasis at age 70. Multiple nodules visible on CT scan. Patient is 5'7", 108 lbs with BMI of 17.

Made deliberate decision to NOT take MAC antibiotic treatment (Big 3 regimen). Chose conservative management with airway clearance only: 7% hypertonic saline nebulization, postural drainage, and autogenic drainage techniques. Reason: concerns about antibiotic toxicity and body's inability to tolerate 18-24 month treatment course.

First negative sputum culture for MAC approximately 6 months after diagnosis, achieved with airway clearance alone (no antibiotics). This represents conversion to negative WITHOUT antimicrobial treatment - highly significant finding.
Second consecutive negative MAC culture at 12 months post-diagnosis. Continuing airway clearance regimen with sustained success.
Third consecutive negative MAC culture at 24 months (2 years) post-diagnosis. Airway clearance-only approach continues to maintain MAC suppression.

Fourth consecutive negative MAC culture at 33 months post-diagnosis. Nearly 3 years MAC-free with airway clearance only. However, Pseudomonas aeruginosa progressed from light growth to heavy growth, requiring treatment decision.

Made decision to undergo 3-week course of IV ceftazidime to treat progressing Pseudomonas aeruginosa (light → heavy growth) before it becomes mucoid (more resistant). Nervous about IV antibiotics due to Infectious Disease doctor's warning that 'it usually returns, sometimes with a vengeance.' Notably, patient willing to treat Pseudomonas but maintains firm stance against MAC antibiotic treatment.

Three years after MAC diagnosis, patient reports maintaining active lifestyle despite ongoing challenges. Struggles with fatigue and feeling 'airway clearance dictates my life' due to phlegm buildup 2 hours after eating (requiring mid-day autogenic drainage). Silent reflux complicates mucus management. Weight remains low (108 lbs, BMI 17) despite efforts. However, no shortness of breath, no chronic cough, still walking/hiking with dogs twice daily. Overall assessment: challenging but acceptable quality of life without antibiotic treatment.

timelines.key_insight: EXCEPTIONAL WATCH-AND-WAIT SUCCESS: Achieved sustained MAC culture negativity (33+ months, 4 consecutive negative tests) through airway clearance alon
